The combat has about as much strategic depth as Yahtzee; as in, it relies entirely on luck of the dice. Nothing is more frustrating than seeing your huge invasion force crushed by a single foot soldier who keeps rolling sixes on defense. You might as well decide the battle outcome using a coin toss. It's be a lot quicker.

Secondly, the map design means that all continents have choke-points that cannot be flanked. This leaves the attacker with two choices:

1. Brute force their way through the choke-point and pray for good dice rolls in combat.
2. Go all the way around the map to attack from another angle (assuming your opponent hasn't bottlenecked that area too).

However #2 doesn't apply if attacking Australia, because Australia only has ONE choke-point in Indonesia. This gives the defending player a huge advantage as they don't have to spread their forces at all. (If you image search for the Risk board, you'll see exactly what I'm talking about)

The bad map design also creates a "runaway leader" problem. The number of troops you get per turn is dependent on how many territories you own. If you own a whole continent you get a bonus. In every game I've played, the first player to own two continents ends up winning. Not only will they get far more troops that everyone else per turn, the choke-point map design allows them to turtle up until they have a huge army. This is especially true for the player who holds Australia.

Unsurprisingly, we only played this game twice before it was permanently shelved. Don't waste your money on it.

For the kind of ubiquitous MB/Parker/Hasbro mass market game "everyone" has grown up with and that many seasoned board gamers tend to only examine with a clothespin on their nostrils, Risk holds up remarkably well. Its combat encounters are simple and to the point (plus numerous enough that die rolls tend to even out), both its economy and dice play reward aggressive play (while the map still offers some defensive choke points), and the reinforcement escalation acts both as a comeback mechanic and a finisher.

The main downside is that while the default world domination mode overstays its welcome (not helped replayability-wise by about 3-4 viable game plans, all tied to taking and holding a given continent), the alternate secret objective mode is of a questionable balance. (Especially at lower player counts: controlling 24 territories is a turn 1 possibility at 3 players!) Most optional rules make the game fairer, but at the cost of slowing it down further. Overall there's simply not enough pay-off here to justify the intersection between a relatively high playtime and regular player elimination.
I still have a soft spot for Risk, despite all its flaws.

Being a huge music lover I knew about Risk from the song “Man on the moon” way before I even knew anything about board games. Risk is one of the first area control games. So many games have since evolved from Risk which sadly means playing Risk today feels a bit slow and messy. Having said that Risk still remains one of the more popular board games today, in many ways Risk has paved the way for so many games that came after it, it even gave us Legacy games, and it has a wonderful online app as well. Risk always found new ways to rebrand itself, but in this review we’ll only focus on the original Risk. Risk is a simple wargame that is easily learned. It is perfect for beginners and uses both luck and strategy. Emphasis on LUCK! But a smart player can use tactics to mitigate the luck aspect to a certain degree. The objective of the game is to conquer the world and eliminate opponents' armies. So under no circumstance play this game with someone who is not prepared to battle, because even in the diplomacy parts of the game, they will be left disappointed when the time comes to break alliances.

Aesthetics – 6
The minis are great, yes it’s cheap plastic but it does add to the feel of the game. The Board is okay, but the cards and dice are horrible, typical Hasbro quality.

Replayability – 7
Every game will play differently, but unfortunately there are some tactics that can be used every game to gain an upper hand for example Australia. The most easily defended country in the world, yes because the only way to enter Australia is from Indonesia and nowhere else not even from New Zealand…oh wait, sorry what was that? … so you’re saying New Zealand wasn’t invented yet?... Yup okay, makes sense.
In all honesty, Risk is a decent game to get started with and will keep you satisfied for some time

Theme – 7
The theme of global domination and conquest is definitely there. The plastic minis do help with the theme and you do feel like Napoleon conquering region after region after region Mwhahahaha….

Fun Factor – 6
So this is where the game loses some points. If the Dice gods are on your side then yes it’s a lot of fun but for the other poor bloke, not so much. If you get eliminated early in the game, that’s it, you’re out and your friends keep playing, and this could happen because of people teaming up and that’s never fun in games.

Downtime and rules – 6
The rules are very easy, but downtime is a factor in this game. Huge battles can drag out and having to wait while someone conquers the world can become boring.

OVERALL RATING 6.5

The game is all about maintaining balance while trying to keep yourself in a slightly stronger position. Just blobbing up and taking one arbitrary territory per turn is not a strong strategy. (It's preferable, though, to spreading yourself too thin, which new players tend to do.) You have to wait for the perfect moment to use your card trade-in to wipe out another player, take his or her cards, turn them in again for more armies, and start a chain reaction in which you conquer every player in the turn.

Version notes: until 2003, you had to have 6+ cards for a mid-term trade in, but Hasbro reduced it to 5+. This shortens the length of the game because it makes it easier to start and maintain the chain reaction (it's also more logical). Hasbro also removed the rule that allows you to put 2 bonus armies on a single territory whose card you turn in. That rule was not part of the original rules when the game came out.

I also do have a STRONG preference for original small and large cylindrical pieces or better still 5 and 10mm wooden cubes if pieces rolling away is a problem during your games, as it makes the game overview very easy to interpret and players can concentrate on strategy and diplomacy rather than attempting to count armies on each country on each turn. Have played this a lot. It is a game that works well with house rules to mix things up. We always play with the house rule of when trading cards in 2 armies goes on the country on each of the cards even if you don't own the country. This makes it so you can get an extra 6 armies rather than the extra 2 stated in the rules, but it also could mean that you could be giving your opponent up to 6 more armies. Other house rules we change constantly. My favorite way to play is with 2 boards connecting the Alaskas' to the other board's Kamchatkas'. Then you use two sets of cards with different formats so you can tell which is with which board. You can play up to 12 players that way and it gets pretty intense. In general this game is just a great game engine that leaves you free to make your own that will lead to great table talk and intense anxiety raising moments.
